feed.title: GitHub Jupyter Notebook Daily Trending
feed.subtitle: Daily Trending of Jupyter Notebook in GitHub

entry.title: xl0/lovely-tensors
entry.summary:
Tensors, ready for human consumption

â¤ï¸ Lovely Tensors

Read full docs | ğŸ’˜ Lovely JAX | ğŸ’Ÿ Lovely NumPy | Discord

Install

pip install lovely-tensors

How to use

How often do you find yourself debugging PyTorch code? You dump a tensor to the cell output, and see this:

numbers

tensor([[[-0.3541, -0.3369, -0.4054,  ..., -0.5596, -0.4739,  2.2489],
         [-0.4054, -0.4226, -0.4911,  ..., -0.9192, -0.8507,  2.1633],
         [-0.4739, -0.4739, -0.5424,  ..., -1.0390, -1.0390,  2.1975],
         ...,
         [-0.9020, -0.8335, -0.9363,  ..., -1.4672, -1.2959,  2.2318],
         [-0.8507, -0.7822, -0.9363,  ..., -1.6042, -1.5014,  2.1804],
         [-0.8335, -0.8164, -0.9705,  ..., -1.6555, -1.5528,  2.1119]],

        [[-0.1975, -0.1975, -0.3025,  ..., -0.4776, -0.3725,  2.4111],
         [-0.2500, -0.2325, -0.3375,  ..., -0.7052, -0.6702,  2.3585],
         [-0.3025, -0.2850, -0.3901,  ..., -0.7402, -0.8102,  2.3761],
         ...,
         [-0.4251, -0.2325, -0.3725,  ..., -1.0903, -1.0203,  2.4286],
         [-0.3901, -0.2325, -0.4251,  ..., -1.2304, -1.2304,  2.4111],
         [-0.4076, -0.2850, -0.4776,  ..., -1.2829, -1.2829,  2.3410]],

        [[-0.6715, -0.9853, -0.8807,  ..., -0.9678, -0.6890,  2.3960],
         [-0.7238, -1.0724, -0.9678,  ..., -1.2467, -1.0201,  2.3263],
         [-0.8284, -1.1247, -1.0201,  ..., -1.2641, -1.1596,  2.3786],
         ...,
         [-1.2293, -1.4733, -1.3861,  ..., -1.5081, -1.2641,  2.5180],
         [-1.1944, -1.4559, -1.4210,  ..., -1.6476, -1.4733,  2.4308],
         [-1.2293, -1.5256, -1.5081,  ..., -1.6824, -1.5256,  2.3611]]])

Was it really useful for you, as a human, to see all these numbers?

What is the shape? The size?
What are the statistics?
Are any of the values nan or inf?
Is it an image of a man holding a tench?

import lovely_tensors as lt

lt.monkey_patch()

__repr__

numbers # torch.Tensor

tensor[3, 196, 196] n=115248 xâˆˆ[-2.118, 2.640] Î¼=-0.388 Ïƒ=1.073

Better, huh?

numbers[1,:6,1] # Still shows values if there are not too many.

tensor[6] xâˆˆ[-0.443, -0.197] Î¼=-0.311 Ïƒ=0.091 [-0.197, -0.232, -0.285, -0.373, -0.443, -0.338]

spicy = numbers[0,:12,0].clone()

spicy[0] *= 10000
spicy[1] /= 10000
spicy[2] = float('inf')
spicy[3] = float('-inf')
spicy[4] = float('nan')

spicy = spicy.reshape((2,6))
spicy # Spicy stuff

tensor[2, 6] n=12 xâˆˆ[-3.541e+03, -4.054e-05] Î¼=-393.842 Ïƒ=1.180e+03 +Inf! -Inf! NaN!

torch.zeros(10, 10) # A zero tensor - make it obvious

tensor[10, 10] all_zeros

spicy.v # Verbose

tensor[2, 6] n=12 xâˆˆ[-3.541e+03, -4.054e-05] Î¼=-393.842 Ïƒ=1.180e+03 +Inf! -Inf! NaN!
tensor([[-3.5405e+03, -4.0543e-05,         inf,        -inf,         nan, -6.1093e-01],
        [-6.1093e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01]])

spicy.p # The plain old way

tensor([[-3.5405e+03, -4.0543e-05,         inf,        -inf,         nan, -6.1093e-01],
        [-6.1093e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01]])

Going .deeper

numbers.deeper

tensor[3, 196, 196] n=115248 xâˆˆ[-2.118, 2.640] Î¼=-0.388 Ïƒ=1.073
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-2.118, 2.249] Î¼=-0.324 Ïƒ=1.036
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-1.966, 2.429] Î¼=-0.274 Ïƒ=0.973
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-1.804, 2.640] Î¼=-0.567 Ïƒ=1.178

# You can go deeper if you need to
numbers[:,:3,:5].deeper(2)

tensor[3, 3, 5] n=45 xâˆˆ[-1.316, -0.197] Î¼=-0.593 Ïƒ=0.306
  tensor[3, 5] n=15 xâˆˆ[-0.765, -0.337] Î¼=-0.492 Ïƒ=0.124
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.440, -0.337] Î¼=-0.385 Ïƒ=0.041 [-0.354, -0.337, -0.405, -0.440, -0.388]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.662, -0.405] Î¼=-0.512 Ïƒ=0.108 [-0.405, -0.423, -0.491, -0.577, -0.662]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.765, -0.474] Î¼=-0.580 Ïƒ=0.125 [-0.474, -0.474, -0.542, -0.645, -0.765]
  tensor[3, 5] n=15 xâˆˆ[-0.513, -0.197] Î¼=-0.321 Ïƒ=0.099
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.303, -0.197] Î¼=-0.243 Ïƒ=0.055 [-0.197, -0.197, -0.303, -0.303, -0.215]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.408, -0.232] Î¼=-0.327 Ïƒ=0.084 [-0.250, -0.232, -0.338, -0.408, -0.408]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.513, -0.285] Î¼=-0.394 Ïƒ=0.102 [-0.303, -0.285, -0.390, -0.478, -0.513]
  tensor[3, 5] n=15 xâˆˆ[-1.316, -0.672] Î¼=-0.964 Ïƒ=0.176
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-0.985, -0.672] Î¼=-0.846 Ïƒ=0.123 [-0.672, -0.985, -0.881, -0.776, -0.916]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-1.212, -0.724] Î¼=-0.989 Ïƒ=0.179 [-0.724, -1.072, -0.968, -0.968, -1.212]
    tensor[5] xâˆˆ[-1.316, -0.828] Î¼=-1.058 Ïƒ=0.179 [-0.828, -1.125, -1.020, -1.003, -1.316]

Now in .rgb color

The important queston - is it our man?

numbers.rgb

Maaaaybe? Looks like someone normalized him.

in_stats = ( (0.485, 0.456, 0.406),     # mean 
             (0.229, 0.224, 0.225) )    # std

# numbers.rgb(in_stats, cl=True) # For channel-last input format
numbers.rgb(in_stats)

Itâ€™s indeed our hero, the Tenchman!

.plt the statistics

(numbers+3).plt


(numbers+3).plt(center="mean", max_s=1000)


(numbers+3).plt(center="range")

See the .chans

# .chans will map values betwen [0,1] to colors.
# Make our values fit into that range to avoid clipping.
mean = torch.tensor(in_stats[0])[:,None,None]
std = torch.tensor(in_stats[1])[:,None,None]
numbers_01 = (numbers*std + mean)
numbers_01

tensor[3, 196, 196] n=115248 xâˆˆ[0., 1.000] Î¼=0.361 Ïƒ=0.248

numbers_01.chans

Letâ€™s try with a Convolutional Neural Network

from torchvision.models import vgg11

features: torch.nn.Sequential = vgg11().features

# I saved the first 5 layers in "features.pt"
_ = features.load_state_dict(torch.load("../features.pt"), strict=False)

# Activatons of the second max pool layer of VGG11
acts = (features[:6](numbers[None])[0]/2) # /2 to reduce clipping
acts

tensor[128, 49, 49] n=307328 xâˆˆ[0., 12.508] Î¼=0.367 Ïƒ=0.634 grad DivBackward0

acts.chans

Grouping

# Make 8 images with progressively higher brightness and stack them 2x2x2.
eight_images = (torch.stack([numbers]*8)
                    .add(torch.linspace(-3, 3, 8)[:,None,None,None])
                    .mul(torch.tensor(in_stats[1])[:,None,None])
                    .add(torch.tensor(in_stats[0])[:,None,None])
                    .clamp(0,1)
                    .view(2,2,2,3,196,196)
)
eight_images

tensor[2, 2, 2, 3, 196, 196] n=921984 xâˆˆ[0., 1.000] Î¼=0.411 Ïƒ=0.369

eight_images.rgb


# Weights of the second conv layer of VGG11
features[3].weight

Parameter containing:
Parameter[128, 64, 3, 3] n=73728 xâˆˆ[-0.783, 0.776] Î¼=-0.004 Ïƒ=0.065 grad

Quick and dirty normalization. I want +/- 2Ïƒ to fall in the range [0..1]

weights = features[3].weight.data
weights = weights / (2*2*weights.std()) # *2 because we want 2Ïƒ on both sides, so 4Ïƒ
weights += weights.std() * 2
weights.plt


# Weights of the second conv layer (64ch -> 128ch) of VGG11,
# grouped per output channel.
weights.chans(frame_px=1, gutter_px=0)

Itâ€™s a bit hard to see. Scale up 10x, but onyl show the first 4 filters.

weights[:4].chans(frame_px=1, gutter_px=0, scale=10)

Without .monkey_patch

lt.lovely(spicy)

tensor[2, 6] n=12 xâˆˆ[-3.541e+03, -4.054e-05] Î¼=-393.842 Ïƒ=1.180e+03 +Inf! -Inf! NaN!

lt.lovely(spicy, verbose=True)

tensor[2, 6] n=12 xâˆˆ[-3.541e+03, -4.054e-05] Î¼=-393.842 Ïƒ=1.180e+03 +Inf! -Inf! NaN!
tensor([[-3.5405e+03, -4.0543e-05,         inf,        -inf,         nan, -6.1093e-01],
        [-6.1093e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.9380e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01, -5.4243e-01]])

lt.lovely(numbers, depth=1)

tensor[3, 196, 196] n=115248 xâˆˆ[-2.118, 2.640] Î¼=-0.388 Ïƒ=1.073
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-2.118, 2.249] Î¼=-0.324 Ïƒ=1.036
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-1.966, 2.429] Î¼=-0.274 Ïƒ=0.973
  tensor[196, 196] n=38416 xâˆˆ[-1.804, 2.640] Î¼=-0.567 Ïƒ=1.178

lt.rgb(numbers, in_stats)


lt.plot(numbers, center="mean")


lt.chans(numbers_01)

SVMå®ç°

æ”¯æŒå‘é‡æœº(SVM)çš„å®ç° | ç¬¬14å¤©

ä»Šå¤©æˆ‘åœ¨çº¿æ€§ç›¸å…³æ•°æ®ä¸Šå®ç°äº†SVMã€‚ä½¿ç”¨Scikit-Learnåº“ã€‚åœ¨scikit-learnä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰SVCåˆ†ç±»å™¨ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨å®ƒæ¥å®Œæˆè¿™ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ã€‚å°†åœ¨ä¸‹ä¸€æ¬¡å®ç°æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨kernel-trickã€‚Pythonä»£ç è§æ­¤å¤„,Jupyter notebookè§æ­¤å¤„ã€‚

æœ´ç´ è´å¶æ–¯åˆ†ç±»å™¨(Naive Bayes Classifier)å’Œé»‘ç›’æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ (Black Box Machine Learning) | ç¬¬15å¤©

å­¦ä¹ ä¸åŒç±»å‹çš„æœ´ç´ è´å¶æ–¯åˆ†ç±»å™¨åŒæ—¶å¼€å§‹Bloombergçš„è¯¾ç¨‹ã€‚è¯¾ç¨‹åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯é»‘ç›’æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ã€‚å®ƒç»™å‡ºäº†é¢„æµ‹å‡½æ•°ï¼Œç‰¹å¾æå–ï¼Œå­¦ä¹ ç®—æ³•ï¼Œæ€§èƒ½è¯„ä¼°ï¼Œäº¤å‰éªŒè¯ï¼Œæ ·æœ¬åå·®ï¼Œéå¹³ç¨³æ€§ï¼Œè¿‡åº¦æ‹Ÿåˆå’Œè¶…å‚æ•°è°ƒæ•´çš„æ•´ä½“è§‚ç‚¹ã€‚

é€šè¿‡å†…æ ¸æŠ€å·§å®ç°æ”¯æŒå‘é‡æœº | ç¬¬16å¤©

ä½¿ç”¨Scikit-Learnåº“å®ç°äº†SVMç®—æ³•ä»¥åŠå†…æ ¸å‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¯¥å‡½æ•°å°†æˆ‘ä»¬çš„æ•°æ®ç‚¹æ˜ å°„åˆ°æ›´é«˜ç»´åº¦ä»¥æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€ä½³è¶…å¹³é¢ã€‚

åœ¨Courseraå¼€å§‹æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ çš„ä¸“ä¸šè¯¾ç¨‹ | ç¬¬17å¤©

åœ¨1å¤©å†…å®Œæˆç¬¬1å‘¨å’Œç¬¬2å‘¨å†…å®¹ä»¥åŠå­¦ä¹ è¯¾ç¨‹ä¸­çš„é€»è¾‘å›å½’ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œã€‚

ç»§ç»­Courseraä¸Šçš„æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ä¸“ä¸šè¯¾ç¨‹ | ç¬¬18å¤©

å®Œæˆè¯¾ç¨‹1ã€‚ç”¨Pythonè‡ªå·±å®ç°ä¸€ä¸ªç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œã€‚

å­¦ä¹ é—®é¢˜å’ŒYaser Abu-Mostafaæ•™æˆ | ç¬¬19å¤©

å¼€å§‹Yaser Abu-Mostafaæ•™æˆçš„Caltechæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ è¯¾ç¨‹-CS156ä¸­çš„è¯¾ç¨‹1ã€‚è¿™åŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ˜¯å¯¹å³å°†åˆ°æ¥çš„è¯¾ç¨‹çš„ä¸€ç§ä»‹ç»ã€‚ä»–ä¹Ÿä»‹ç»äº†æ„ŸçŸ¥ç®—æ³•ã€‚

æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ä¸“ä¸šè¯¾ç¨‹2 | ç¬¬20å¤©

å®Œæˆæ”¹è¿›æ·±åº¦ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œç¬¬1å‘¨å†…å®¹ï¼šå‚æ•°è°ƒæ•´ï¼Œæ­£åˆ™åŒ–å’Œä¼˜åŒ–ã€‚

ç½‘é¡µæœç½— | ç¬¬21å¤©

è§‚çœ‹äº†ä¸€äº›å…³äºå¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨Beautiful Soupè¿›è¡Œç½‘ç»œçˆ¬è™«çš„æ•™ç¨‹ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿æ”¶é›†ç”¨äºæ„å»ºæ¨¡å‹çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚

å­¦ä¹ è¿˜å¯è¡Œå—? | ç¬¬22å¤©

å®ŒæˆYaser Abu-Mostafaæ•™æˆçš„Caltechæœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ è¯¾ç¨‹-CS156ä¸­çš„è¯¾ç¨‹2ã€‚å­¦ä¹ Hoeffdingä¸ç­‰å¼ã€‚

å†³ç­–æ ‘ | ç¬¬23å¤©

ç»Ÿè®¡å­¦ä¹ ç†è®ºçš„ä»‹ç» | ç¬¬24å¤©

Bloomberg MLè¯¾ç¨‹çš„ç¬¬3è¯¾ä»‹ç»äº†ä¸€äº›æ ¸å¿ƒæ¦‚å¿µï¼Œå¦‚è¾“å…¥ç©ºé—´ï¼ŒåŠ¨ä½œç©ºé—´ï¼Œç»“æœç©ºé—´ï¼Œé¢„æµ‹å‡½æ•°ï¼ŒæŸå¤±å‡½æ•°å’Œå‡è®¾ç©ºé—´ã€‚

å†³ç­–æ ‘ | ç¬¬25å¤©

å†³ç­–æ ‘å®ç°

è·³åˆ°å¤ä¹ çº¿æ€§ä»£æ•° | ç¬¬26å¤©

å‘ç°YouTubeä¸€ä¸ªç¥å¥‡çš„é¢‘é“3Blue1Brownï¼Œå®ƒæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ’­æ”¾åˆ—è¡¨ã€Šçº¿æ€§ä»£æ•°çš„æœ¬è´¨ã€‹ã€‚çœ‹å®Œäº†4ä¸ªè§†é¢‘ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬äº†å‘é‡ï¼Œçº¿æ€§ç»„åˆï¼Œè·¨åº¦ï¼ŒåŸºå‘é‡ï¼Œçº¿æ€§å˜æ¢å’ŒçŸ©é˜µä¹˜æ³•ã€‚

Bç«™æ’­æ”¾åˆ—è¡¨åœ¨è¿™é‡Œã€‚

è·³åˆ°å¤ä¹ çº¿æ€§ä»£æ•° | ç¬¬27å¤©

ç»§ç»­è§‚çœ‹äº†4ä¸ªè§†é¢‘ï¼Œå†…å®¹åŒ…æ‹¬ä¸‰ç»´å˜æ¢ã€è¡Œåˆ—å¼ã€é€†çŸ©é˜µã€åˆ—ç©ºé—´ã€é›¶ç©ºé—´å’Œéæ–¹çŸ©é˜µã€‚

Bç«™æ’­æ”¾åˆ—è¡¨åœ¨è¿™é‡Œã€‚

è·³åˆ°å¤ä¹ çº¿æ€§ä»£æ•° | ç¬¬28å¤©

ç»§ç»­è§‚çœ‹äº†3ä¸ªè§†é¢‘ï¼Œå†…å®¹åŒ…æ‹¬ç‚¹ç§¯å’Œå‰ç§¯ã€‚

entry.title: RSNA/AI-Deep-Learning-Lab-2022
entry.summary:
RSNA AI Deep Learning Lab 2022

Intro

Welcome Deep Learners!

This document provides all the information you need to participate in the RSNA AI Deep Learning Lab. This set of classes provides a hands-on opportunity to engage with deep learning tools, write basic algorithms, learn how to organize data to implement deep learning and improve your understanding of AI technology.

The classes will be held in the RSNA AI Deep Learning Lab classroom, which is located in the Lakeside Learning Center, Level 3. Here's the schedule of classes. CME credit is available for each session.

Requirements

All lessons are designed to run in Google Colab, which is a free web-based version of Jupyter hosted by Google. You will need a Google account (eg, gmail) to use Colab. If you don't already have a Google account, please create one in advance at the account sign-up page. You can delete the account when you complete the lessons if you wish.

We recommend that you use a computer with a recent vintage processor running the Chrome browser.

Class Schedule

Date / Time Class Notebooks
Sunday, November 27, 2022
Sun 10:30-11:30 am DICOM Data Wrangling with Python (Beginner friendly) Notebook
Sun 12:00-1:00 pm Data Processing & Curation for Deep Learning (Beginner friendly) Notebook
Monday, November 28, 2022
Mon 9:00-10:00 am NCI Imaging Data Commons: Curated data and Reproducible AI workflows (Beginner friendly) See README in course folder
Mon 10:30-11:30 am Accessing freely available public datasets from The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA) (Beginner friendly) Notebook
Mon 12:00-1:00 pm MedNIST Exam Classification with MONAI (Beginner friendly) Notebook
Mon 1:30-2:30 pm CT Body Part Classification (Beginner friendly) Notebook #1, Notebook #2
Mon 3:00-4:00 pm Basics of NLP in Radiology (Beginner friendly) Notebook
Tuesday, November 29, 2022
Tues 10:00-11:00 am YOLO: Bounding Box Segmentation & Classification - Part 1 Notebook
Tues 11:30 am-12:30 pm Generative Adversarial Networks Notebook
Tues 1:00-2:00 pm Best Practices for Model Training: Architectures, Hyperparameters & Optimization Course Faculty will provide instructions
Tue 3:00-4:00 pm NLP: Text Classification with Transformers Notebook
Wednesday, November 30, 2022
Wed 10:00-11:00 am YOLO: Bounding Box Segmentation & Classification - Part 2 Notebook
Wed 11:30 am-12:30 pm Building custom deep learning models with PyTorch Notebook
Wed 1:00-2:00 pm DICOM In, DICOM Out for Segmentation Notebook
Thursday, December 1, 2022
Thurs 9:00-10:00 am Accelerate your AI-based medical imaging research with MONAI Core on SageMaker Course Faculty will provide instructions
Thurs 10:30-11:30 am Multimodal Fusion for Pulmonary Embolism Detection Using CTs and Patient EMR Notebook
